prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 observations of Orion's giant proplyds
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Obtain hight resolution single pointing observations of 3 of Orion's largets silhouette disks

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We wish to resolve the Doppler motions in outflows, Keplerian rotation, and any motions above the sound speed of 0.2 km/s as well as CO entrained by the fast (100 km/s) jets. The sound speed is about 0.2 km/s. Keplerian motion will broaddend lines to about 5 to 20 km/s in the inner 0.1" beam (depending on the stellar mass). Two disks power protostellar jets with ~100 km/s velocities. Entrained CO might be detectable with velocities of 10s of km/s. Disk winds are expected to have speeds of a few km/s. Hence the need for bandwidth of about 100 km/s in CO. Our Cycle 0 data shows that CO is seen in absorption in 114-426 at all velocities becasue of the bright (80 K) background. Some absorption is also seen in the other 2 targes at some velocities. We thus set a spectral resolution reuqirement of about 0.2 km/s.
In addition to the HCN, HCO+,and CO lines, the Band 7 observations target two SO2 lines wich may be an indication of hot-core ("hot corino") chemistry in the inner portions of the disk. SiC2 is also a hot core tracer.

Our Cycle 0 observations with 0.5" beam show that the largest disk is about 3" in diameter. We want to improve the angular resolution, and increase our sensitivty to small scale structure. The Bally et al. (2015) analysis of 114-426 shows that dust emission was only seen in the inner 300 AU portion of the 900 AU diameter visual-wavelength silhouette. The column density limit set by the noise correpsonds to a higher dust column density than the column density required to explain the extinction of visual and near-IR light. Our longer integration times are designed to reach the column density estimated from visual extinction. Additionally, the HST images show that the disk vertical thickness is about 0.2", and was therefore beam diluted by the Cycle 0 observations. We request 0.1" resolution to resolve the disk scale-height of the esge-on 114-426 disk.

Typical gas temperatures in at the location of our target in Orion range from 5 to 20 K depending or the radiation environment. The main tracers we propose to observe, CO, HCO+, and HCN are expected to be thermalized and have high opacity and thus have line temperatures in this range. The sound speed is about 0.2 km/s. Keplerian motion will broaddend lines to about 5 to 20 km/s in the inner 0.1" beam (depending on the stellar mass).
Our Cycle 0 observstions (Mann et al 2014; Bally et al. 2015) show that the line temperatures range from 5 to 20 K and continuum fluxes from 3 mJy per 0.5" beam to about 100 mJy per beam. We need to devote one setting to a broad-band continuum measurement to reach the column density sensitivity.
Although the backgorund of the Orion A cloud is bright (up to 80 K along the line of sight, at 0.1 to a few arc-second scales, the the fluctuaations caused by this strucutre are expected to be relatively small. The spatial filtering of the 12-m array will be more complete than in our Cycle 0 observations; though backgorund intensity variations dominated the noise at the radial velocities where the background is bright, they did not seriously impact the disk science.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 observations of Orion's giant proplyds
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Obtain hight resolution single pointing observations of 3 of Orion's largets silhouette disks in the band 6 continuum and CO to constrain exctiation conditions.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The sound speed is about 0.2 km/s. Keplerian motion will broaddend lines to about 5 to 20 km/s in the inner 0.1" beam (depending on the stellar mass). Two of the disks power protostellar jets with ~100 km/s velocities. We wish to resolve the Doppler motions in outflows, Keplerian rortation, and any motions above the sound speed of 0.2 km/s as well as CO entrained by the fast (100 km/s) jets. Entrained CO might be detectable with velocities of 10s of km/s. Also, disk winds are expected to have speeds of a few km/s. Hence the need for bandwidth of abotu 100 km/s in CO. Our Cycle 0 data shows that CO is seen in absorption in 114-426 at all velocities becasue of the bright (80 K) background. Some absorption is also seen in the other 2 targes at some velocities. We thus set a spectral resoltuion reuqirement of about 0.2 km/s
The Band 6 observations target C18O and 13CO to check the opacity of the 12CO lines, as well as SiO which is a sensitive shock tracer which can identify shock in the outflows, of where wide-angle components of the flow or strong radiation fields might interact with the disk.

Our Cycle 0 observations with 0.5" beam show that the largest disk is about 3" in diameter. We want to improve the angular reosolution, and increase our sensitivty to small scale structure. The Bally et al. (2015) analysis of 114-426 shows that dust emission was only seen in the inner 300 AU portion of the 900 AU diameter visual-wavelength silhouette. The column density limit set by the noise correpsonds to a higher dust column density than the column density required to explain the extinction of visual and near-IR light. Our longer integration times are dsigned to reach the column density estimated from visual extinction. Additionally, the HST images hsow that the disk vertical thickness is about 0.2", and was therefore beam diluted by the Cycle 0 observations.
We request 0.13" resolution to resolve the disk scale-height of the edge-on 114-426 disk. The OT doen not allow 0.1" angular resolution to be reached, even with a 1.0" largest anglular scale specification, despite the adverised 10 km baselines allowed in Band 6. Although 0.13" is slightly worse thatn the resolution in Band 7 (0.1"), the analyses requiring beam-mattched observations can be carried out by convolving the 0.1" Band 7 data to match the 0.13" Band 6 data.

Typical gas temperatures at the location of our targets in Orion range from 5 to 20 K depending or the radiation environment. The main tracers we propose to observe, CO, HCO+, and HCN are expected to be thermalized and have high opacity and thus have line temperatures in this range. The sound speed is about 0.2 km/s. Keplerian motion will broaddend lines to about 5 to 20 km/s in the inner 0.1" beam (depending on the stellar mass).
Our Cycle 0 observstions (Mann et al 2014; Bally et al. 2015) show that the line temperatures range from 5 to 20 K and continuum fluxes from 3 mJy per 0.5" beam to about 100 mJy per beam. We need to deveote one setting to a broad-band continuum measurement to reach the column density sensitivity.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: High angular resolution Band 6 & 7 observations of Orion's three largest protoplanetary disks 114-426, 216-0939, 253-1536A & its smaller companion, 253-1536B, will be used to measure radial gradients in disk gas and dust properties, disk structure, the masses of their central stars using the disk rotation curves, and the tidal streams and distortions in the binary. The three target systems are the best characterized protoplanetary systems in Orion since they have been observed with HST and ALMA in Cycle 0. Despite their similar angular (and physical) dimensions, the disk masses span a wide range from 3 to 80 times the mass of Jupiter; the central stars range from 0.4 to 3.5 Solar masses. The three targets probe a wide range of environments from HII region interiors to shielded dark cloud environments. The dust spectral index, measured from 0.85 to 1.3 mm will be used to search for evidence of grain growth as a function of disk radius. The lines will be used to constrain excitation conditions and gas temperatures in the disk coronae, to study disk winds and entrained molecular gas at the base of outflows, and dense gas tracers will be used to probe disk structure and kinematics.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astrophysical and Planetary Sciences, Colorado at Boulder, Univ of
